top10.text:
Nickel carbonate, also known as nickelous carbonate, is a chemical compound. Its chemical formula is NiCO 3 . It contains nickel in its +2 oxidation state. It also contains carbonate ions. ==Properties==
Nickel carbonate is a pale green solid. It does not dissolve in water. It reacts with acids to make carbon dioxide.
top10.title: Nickel(II) carbonate

top10.text: Fluvial terrace is an abandoned floodplain with a long, narrow stairs that is formed when the river flowed at a higher level than at present. Fluvial terrace consists of two parts; a tread, which is the flat surface at the upper side of fluvial terrace, and a scarp, which is the steep slope connecting the tread to the downside.
top10.title: Fluvial terrace

top10.text: floor of the Mediterranean Sea. It is next to a rough quarter circle from Calabria, south of Crete, to the southwest corner of Turkey, and from there eastwards south of Turkey, with Cyprus. tectonic theory subducting under Eurasian and Anatolian Plate plows up the floor of the Mediterranean, lifting it from the seabed, and then above sea level, making the island of Cyprus.
top10.title: Mediterranean Ridge

top10.text: The Gulf or Bay of Honduras is a large inlet of the Caribbean Sea. It indents the coasts of Belize, Guatemala, and Honduras. From north to south, it runs for approximately 200 km from Dangriga, Belize, to La Ceiba, Honduras. The inner Gulf of Honduras is lined by the Belize Barrier Reef. It forms the southern part of the 900 km long Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System.
top10.title: Gulf of Honduras

top10.text: are formed by some microbial mats as the microbes slowly move upwards to avoid being smothered by sediment. of a non-stromatolite microbial mat. The image shows the location, in the Burgsvik beds of Sweden, where the texture was first identified as evidence of a microbial mat. A microbial mat is a multi-layered sheet of microorganisms, mainly bacteria and archaea.
top10.title: Microbial mat

top10.text:
Cobalt  is a chemical element. It has an atomic number of 27 and an atomic mass of about 59. It is a metal. ==Properties==
 
 
Cobalt is a transition metal. It is shiny and conducts electricity. It is magnetic. It is a hard metal. It is moderately chemical reaction
top10.title: Cobalt

top10.text: Sierra Nevada Mountains and flows west and north to its end at San Francisco Bay, at the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta. tributaries are Stanislaus rivers. The river was once one of the richest river ecosystems in California. However, now over   of the river is dry except during floods, because lots of water has been taken away for irrigation.
top10.title: San Joaquin River

top10.text:
====Sulfur acids====
Mixture of sulfur oxides and water
*Sulfurous acid, unstable, weak
*Sulfuric acid, stable, strong acid, most used chemical after water loses one acidic proton
*Hydrogen sulfide, weak smelly gas, becomes acidic when dissolved in water

====Sulfides====
 
Salts of hydrogen sulfide
*Ammonium sulfide, used in stink bombs
*Antimony trisulfide, used in match heads
*Arsenic trisulfide, less toxic arsenic compound
*Barium sulfide, used to make barium from barium sulfate
*Bismuth sulfide, bismuth ore
*Iron sulfide, found as pyrite naturally
*Lead sulfide, found as galena naturally
*Selenium disulfide, used in hair treatment creams
*Potassium sulfide, reacts with water
*Silver sulfide, tarnish on silver objects
*Thallium sulfide, infrared detector
*Tin sulfide, dark brown solid
*Tin sulfide, gold solid, "mosaic gold"
*Zinc sulfide, used in fluorescent bulbs

====Sulfites====
 
Salts of sulfurous acid
*Sodium sulfite, used to preserve dried foods
*Potassium sulfite, used to preserve foods

====Sulfates and bisulfates====
 
Salts of sulfuric acid
*Alums, all of them
*Aluminium sulfate
*Ammonium sulfate, used in fertilizers
*Barium sulfate, used to take X-rays of digestive system
*Cobalt sulfate, used in pigments
*Copper sulfate, used to kill algae
*Chromium sulfate, used to make chrome alum reduction 
*Iron sulfate, rare
*Lead sulfate, white solid in lead acid batteries
*Manganese sulfate, used to add manganese to soil
*Nickel sulfate, used to make nickel compounds
*Sodium bisulfate, used in lowering pH
*Sodium sulfate, used in detergents and paper making
*Thallium sulfate, colorless odorless tasteless highly toxic
*Tin sulfate, used to make other tin compounds
*Zinc sulfate, used in pigments

====Other sulfur compounds====
;Sulfur compounds
*Sulfur chloride, yellow liquid

;Sulfur compounds
*Sulfur chloride, red odorous liquid

;Sulfur compounds
*Disulfur dinitride, colorless solid
*Tetrasulfur tetranitride, orange solid

;Sulfur compounds
*Sulfur tetrafluoride, colorless toxic gas

;Sulfur compounds
*Disulfur decafluoride, colorless toxic liquid

;Sulfur compounds
*Sulfur hexafluoride, colorless heavy gas

==Occurrence and preparation==
 
Sulfur can be found in the earth near volcanoes.
top10.title: Sulfur

orig:
But every night we would report to "Mission Control" -- different masks they're wearing. It could look like they didn't take the work seriously, but they really did because they're going to have to live with radioactivity their whole life. And so what we did with them is that we'd discuss the data we collected that day, and talk about where we should be going next -- strategy, itinerary, etc... And to do this, we built a very rough topographical map of the region around the nuclear power plant. And so we built the elevation map, we sprinkled pigments to represent real-time data for radioactivity, and we sprayed water to simulate the rainfall. And with this we could see that the radioactive dust was washing from the top of the mountain into the river system, and leaking into the ocean. So it was a rough estimate.
But with this in mind, we organized this expedition, which was the closest civilians have been to the nuclear power plant. We are sailing 1.5 kilometers away from the nuclear power plant, and with the help of the local fisherman, we are collecting sediment from the seabed with a custom sediment sampler we've invented and built. We pack the sediment into small bags, we then dispatch them to hundreds of small bags that we send to different universities, and we produce the map of the seabed radioactivity, especially in estuaries where the fish will reproduce, and I will hope that we will have improved the safety of the local fishermen and of your favorite sushi.
